it smells a bit like fairy liquid, my first impression of the glass was, what have i just paid 3 quid for, but it’s well worth it, looks very good, a wonderful complex flavour. It’s darn better than regular P*ss tasting kronenbourg. thumb goes up
Well, that was great. It tastes like lime, but it is Wheat, anyway was yummi, a little sour, but nice I like more of it.

500ml bottle from Sainsburys. Cloudy banana  colour with lasting tight white head. Nice bubblegum and tropical fruit flavours. Quite creamy in mouth with good lemon acids. More tropical fruit flavours on the end. As a mango/passionfruit drink its quite nice, but as a wheat beer? 
Re-rate. Draught at The Office Folkestone. Just too artificial. Nice fruit flavours, but not  sure this passes for beer.

Can... Straw-colored lager with a mid-sized, creamy, off-white head. Incredible retention. Smells like straw... if anything at all. Tastes like an adjunct-laden, low gravity malt liquor... if that’s possible. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Finishes alcoholic and astringent. Thanks go out to my friend Dai for bringing this one back from her trip to Europe.

I love this beer, tried it on holiday in Northumberland - desperately trying to find local source.  Thinks it’s a woman’s beer - but there are plenty of us out here. Would probably give up the wine if I could find supplies at local ’offie’

Poured pale gold and hazy with a brief head. Aroma puzzled me for a bit until I picked out banana and mango amongst other indefinable fruity notes. Now I quite liked this aroma at first; then I began to wonder if beer ought to smell of such things. I have a shower gel that has a similar odour. What about the taste? A children’s fruit drink - the sort that has pictures of smiling jungle animals on the carton - but sadly a bit of household detergent seems to have got in too. If you knock it back quickly it tastes of virtually nothing. Bottle was cool - otherwise this should be avoided.
Poured cloudy  with a distinctive wheat flavour. A poor example of this genre but why did I expect any better?
Pours a cloudy pale yellow with an interesting cordially-tropical aroma. No way a Belgian White, you can tell it’s trying to copy but it falls way short.....too sweet.
Bottled. Cloudy yellow with light head. Sweet, sticky witbier with a lemon dab type flavour. Lacks body and any spiciness and any impact. On the whole its a fizzy pop rather than a beer, oh well.

Bottled. Cloudy yellow, evaporating head. Smells like those lucky bags of sweets I had when I was a kid, only the bag has been in my pocket for a week and started to ferment. And the flavour is from my childhood, too; it’s Calpol the cough medicine. All bubblegum and thick sweeteners. It’s not a Belgian wit (where’s the spice?) but it is strangely alluring. Like beer for thise who ’don’t like beer’.

A hazy light yellow beer with a dense white nitro head. The aroma is of lemon and pineapple, while the flavor is primarily lemon. It was served very cold - so it reminded me a lot of drinking lemonade. From the flavor, this ought to a Fruit beer. This was a once in a lifetime.

Bottle: CLoudy yellow with a lasting white head. Suprising strong tropical fruit aroma, loads of lemon with a hint of mandarin there too. Pineapple in the flavour, lemon and other fruits. Very refreshing, though lacks spice or depth. Still suprisingly good IMO.

This beer is very intersting, at first the pale clouded yellow appearance looks rather tastey but once tasted the drinker quickly realizes that this beer has a close relationship to the medicines the drinker has had when they were a small child. But after having a few of these the flavour becomes less important.

Bottle from Co-op, Stirchley. Pale clouded yellow appearance, no head. Sticky, thin mouthfeel - a little icey. Flavour is reasonably nice initially - sweet lemon cordial, with honey cough medicine. Gets a bit cloying, tinny and boringly malty as you go on. Workmanlike, but palatable.

Bottle.  Cloudy orange/yellow with a rapidly disappearing head.  Aromas are banana, sweet lemon and lots of perfume. parma violet sweets.  Flavours are sweet lemon barley water with spices with banana and yeast.  Not so tasty as many wits, but a decent refresher.

Bottled.  An ugly hazy pale orange coloured beer with a wispish head.  The aroma is lemons, oranges and grapefruit and is actually quite pleasant if a little syrupy.  The taste is sickly sweet and is more orange juice than lemony.  A wit which lacks any skill.

[bottle from peckhams] appearance is a very light straw colour, cloudy, with a moderate but quickly dispersing head. The nose is fruity in a plastic way, reminding me of fruit salads (the chewy sweet). The body in watery and aggressively carbonated, tastes like perry water. bland and unpleasant to drink.
I was surprised with this one, very fruity taste, enjoyable, a clearer appearance, a sweet taste to it and an overall great experience, this was worth getting a pint of

I must admit this looks really good..typically cloudy with a thick white head.That’s one unusual nose,certainly fruity, spice comes through as it warms up, palate is light, with a well balanced friut/spice flavour..finish is rather short. Very refreshing stuff.. but there’s something about the nose that doesn’t seem right ( artificial???) Is this bottle conditioned or is it artificially cloudy, the white bottle doesn’t let you see if there’s yeast at the bottom of the bottle. Tesco Galashiels, price unkwown as the wife brought it home and lost the receipt
Draught in Blackfriars, Glasgow. Absolutely awful sherbert lemon sweetness just ruined this for me. Fizzy pop. Yeuch.

Hazy, light yellow with slim white head. Citrus and spice aroma. Taste - this beer appears to be the highest RB rated one from Kronenbourg, and I would agree - citrus flavours, fairly highly carbonated, crisp, refreshing, drinkable, thin mouthfeel, lack of character. Overall not too bad.

Bottled, from Tesco. Hazy lemon yellow, thin but sustained white head and low condition. Initialy citric nose that starts lemon and becomes grapefruit with time, joined by a low spicy corriander note. Soft and slight in the mouth with traces of grapefruit and lemon and some chalkiness. Brief citric finish with traces of spice. Halfarsed attempt at a witbier. A halfwit.

Although different to my usual style of beer, an immencly refreshing beer. 
I havnt really tasted anything like this, really thin and no body at all, but citrus and creamy almost feel is excellent.
One to have in summer on a hot day and for a session, nothing special otherwise do to lack of any sort of body.
Keg @ Blonde Bar, Winchester. Lemons and lime aromas. Tangy body but not exciting, just easily drinkable and refreshing.

Lots of interesting tastes in this one.  A picked up strong white wine and grapefruit, but other flavors such as apple, tangerine, and lemon are there.  Very citrusy and acidic.  Has a somewhat unpleasant sparkling quality, a bit too light and carbonated.

Oct 2019. Can from KK shop in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. 5%. Brewed in Malaysia by Carlsberg. A little soapy. Lacks oomph. But drinkable. [2.4]

May 2005. Keg @ Britannia, Chatham. Very pleasant orange aroma, cloudy appearance, washed glass from the dramatic keg tap - all adds to the appeal; and this is a pleasant enough drink - clean, cold and refreshing. The gentle savlon spice, with just a few hints of soap, and gentle but crisp carbonation, all make this quite drinkable - but it does lack character, depth, edge, life... well, it just lacks genuine interest. But it’s great for a refreshing drink, and we did go back for seconds of this rather than the stodgy Deuchars IPA. [3.0]

The fact that this is everywhere and is served next to the dreaful 1664 standard detracts from the start . Pale body and bleached white head atop a bland bubblegum and estery body. For the girls and pansies.
Nice and refreshing, but ultimately a thin palate and little truly interesting in the beer. Looks awesome though, head lasts and you get beautiful lacing right the way down the glass.
PURE EXCELLENCE!!! I had it in the UK..it’s Wonderful!!!!!!!!!!!!! Hope we can get it soon in the States to enjoy.
Pale yellow. Aroma is sourish and fruity from citrus and strawberries (!). Frutiy and yeasty flavor like most weissbiers, maybe a little thin palate.
Nice pale yellow colour, cloudy with a huge white head that lasts and lasts.  Very prominent spicy coriander character, some orange citrus and a crisp finish.  A great witbier.

Keg @ Stockholm Beer Festival
Plenty of lemon. It’s like a Belgian Wit trying to be a German Weiss mix. Refreshing, alright, and interresting beer for a macro. One dimensional in the long run though. It’s alright as a quick one in the summer to refresh your palate.

It was an interesting color ... assisted by the fact that it was frosted mug.  As it is a white, the color is tough to compare due to my limited experience with whites.  I thought it looked like a frosted mug of suds sent from heaven (thats the best I can do with the color, cuz it was so light... but pretty),  The taste was quite sweet, and although it seemed thin, the taste lingered for quite a while.  Almost a fruity taste with some coriander.  Quite a good beer.  Although mine was served much too cold.
It is only distributed to the northern parts of the UK ... I had mine in Edinburough.  It isn’t found anywhere else.

Had this over on Whitehall in London, as well (I believe) somewhere in the depths of Temple Bar with the lawyers.  Excellent taste, expensive price, usually a special tap all for its own.  Soft lemon and fruits taste, floaties, small froth, enjoyable round altogether.  But could you buy it for me please?
Tap@The Corner Store, Covent Garden. Sweet lemon sherbert and dencorub aroma. Body is thin and acidic, spicy, lemony, a bit sweet and eggy.

Draught, at the Priory, Clarkenwell, London 
 Pale foggy yellow colour with a rich, full, foaming white head. Musk, banana and white rose aroma. Served chillingly cold, which was pleasant at the time. Smooth bubblegum and sherbet flavour but relatively soft compared with some.
